article.title: Telecommunications_in_the_Cook_Islands
article.paragraph: EngvarBDecember 2013Use dmy datesDecember 2013Like most countries and territories in Oceania,telecommunications in theCook Islandsis limited by its isolation and low population,with only one major television broadcasting station and six radio stations. However, most residents have a main line or mobile phone. Its telecommunications are mainly provided by Telecom Cook Islands, who is currently working withO3b Networks, Ltd.for faster Internet connection.
article.heading: Telephone
article.paragraph: In July 2012, there were about 7,500 main line telephones, which covers about 98% of the country's population,cite webMaherJulesThriving on a No-fibre Diet in the Cook Islandshttp://www.itu.int/ITU-D/asp/CMS/Events/2012/pacific-bb/S5_CookIslands.pdfPacific Broadband ForumTelecom Cook IslandsFiji28 July 20123 December 2013while there were approximately 7,800 mobile phones in 2009. Telecom Cook Islands, owned bySpark New Zealand,cite press releaseWoodLaurahttp://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20100505005815/enResearch and Markets: Cook Islands – Telecoms, Mobile and Broadband – Satellite Services from O3b Consortium to Bring Faster Broadband in 2011[[Business Wire]]5 May 2010[[Dublin]]3 December 2013is the islands' main telephone system and offers international direct dialling, Internet, email, fax, andTelex. The individual islands are connected by a combination of satelliteearth stations, microwave systems, andvery high frequencyandhigh frequencyradiotelephone; within the islands, service is provided by small exchanges connected to subscribers by open wire, cable, andfibre optic cable. For international communication, they rely on the satellite earth stationIntelsat.CIA World Factbookhttps://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/cw.htmlCook Islands20133 December 2013

article.heading: Broadcasting
Radio
article.paragraph: There are six radio stations in the Cook Islands, with one reaching all islands.As of1997there were 14,000 radios.CIA World Factbookhttp://www.umsl.edu/services/govdocs/wofact2002/geos/cw.htmlCook Islands20014 December 2013
article.heading: Television
article.paragraph: Cook Islands Television broadcasts fromRarotonga, the capital of the Cook Islands, providing a mix of local news and overseas-sourced programs.as of1997there were 4,000 television sets.
article.heading: Internet
article.paragraph: There were 6,000 Internet users in 2009 and 3,562Internet hostsas of 2012.Thecountry code top-level domainfor the Cook Islands is.ck.cite webDelegation Record for .CKhttp://www.iana.org/domains/root/db/ck.html[[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority]]2 December 2013
